title: TomPegden commented OPINION: Theresa May must lead us out of this mess
text:
Comments (1) 
From a business point of view the two-and-a-bit weeks since the referendum have been savage. 
Whether you were an inner or an outer, there is no denying the business community and economy has a whole has been punched in the guts. 
Whether that punch will cause long term damage is yet to be seen, but companies are already starting to feel the pinch. 
As reported on page one of Business Week, Leicester law firm Edward Hands and Lewis has announced that the economic uncertainty has caused it to put aggressive expansion plans on hold. Related content Jeremy Corbyn's Leicestershire supporters rallying round leader as bid to topple him is launched 
This is a confident company that has taken advantage of the deregulation in legal service to grow at a phenomenal pace, creating jobs and security for workers along the way. 
That it has paused that expansion in the light of Brexit paints a stark picture.Hopefully it will be just a temporary setback – until the economy stabilises. 
But it seems inevitable that others will follow. 
It wasn't just the Brexit vote that caused the mess we're in, but David Cameron's immediate announcement that he was stepping down. 
At a time of national upheaval we need a strong Government. 
A Government that can take the bull by the horns and decide exactly what Brexit means. 
A Government that can lead negotiations with the EU confidently. 
A Government that can make Britain better – not worse. 
The pantomime that surrounded Johnson, Fox, Crabb, Gove and Leadsom in the days following the referendum made us a laughing stock. 
Nothing suggested coherence or direction. 
It was a free-for-all which did nothing to placate the fears of business and public alike. 
But when Andrea Leadsom threw the towel in yesterday and gave Theresa May a decisive claim on No 10, the country was given a lifeline. 
Whether you are a right-winger or a leftie, this is the best thing that could have happened under the circumstances. 
The markets reacted accordingly. 
Hopefully general business will too, giving at least a modicum of comfort to companies worried about what happens next. 
Now it is up to Mrs May to get things right, and to lead Britain out of this self-inflicted crisis. 
And Labour could learn something from this too. 
Just as we need strong Government in difficult times, so too do we need strong opposition – to provide the checks and balances democracy requires.
